VOL. XXV. No. 8
NON-ATHLETIC FEE PASSED
UNANIMOUSLY BY
STUDENT-BODY.
Fee to Correspond to Athletic Fee—
Will Include all Non-Athletic Activities on the Campus—Will
be Presented to Trustees
for Sanction.

At the General Assembly of
last week the following resolution
concerning the establishment of a
non-athletic fee was passed by the
student-body by an almost unanimous vote:
ResQlved, That we, the studentbody of Johns Hopkins University,
request the ,Board of Trustees to
establish a fee of $10 to be devoted
to non-athletie activities, which
fee is to be paid by each student
upon entrance to the University
as is the present athletic fee.
Bascom Kennady presented the
subject to the meeting, explaining
the many advantages of the plan
and the tentative scheme of apportionment that has been drawn up.
Such an arrangement, he said, has
worked well at other colleges, removing the chance of failure of the
activities, increasing their efficiency, and placing the burden of
support equally on the shoulders
of all. Several men prominent in
campus activities were next called
on, and were all enthusiastic in
their support. Among them were
Ed Wood, captain of the Football
Team and Athletic Board President; Bill Wood and Elmer Jones,
'football stars; Mullikin, President of the Senior Class; Fedder,
President of the Zionist Society;
Heiner, of the Omicron 'DeJta
Kappa, and Stansbury, of the
Student Council.

BALTIMORE, MD., NOVEMBER 23, 1920

WESTERN MARYLAND FALLS BEFORE
HOPKINS MACHINE
Black and Blue Steam Roller Rolls Up 49 to 0 Score
Against Green and Gold.

The Hopkins' steam roller, after beginning with Haverford and
gathering momentum against St. John's, crushed the Western Maryland eleven last Saturday, and flattened it out to the tune of. 49 to 0.
The desperate efforts of the Green and Gold were completely smothered
by the slashing (play of the "Big Black" team; the Hopkins' backs
dashed almost at will through and around the Up-Staters' line, while
the clever Black and Blue forward gave the secondary defense almost
nothing to do.
John Markell was again responsible for most of the spectacular
back field work, although closely followed by Erie Calkins, who returned
to the game after being out for several weeks. Time after time these
two men, aided by splendid interference, plowed their way for long
gains, and were stopped onlY by Western Maryland's last defense. Even
this finally failed when Markel' scored on a 20-yard run, and Calkins
later on intercepted a forward pass and sprinted 50 yards for a touchdown. Jones and Cashell, although they did their share in carrying
the ball, stood out most clearly on the defensive and backed up the line
in faultless style, while ,Gregg, beside handling the team well, made
the longest run of the day on an interceptod pass, only to lose the result
of his work through a penalty for off-side play.
The highest praise that can be given the Black and Blue line is to
say that it played wit halmost machine-like precision, so that each man
occupied the spotlight at one time 'or another, and no one player stood
far above his fellows. Bill Wood exhibited his usual brilliant game at
end, while "Ti!" Morgan broke through the Green and Gold line with
regularity and downed the runner before he had a chance to start.
Captain Ward, at tackle, and; Langrall and Phillips, on the wings,
were responsible for whatever opposition the Up-Staters were able to
offer to the Hopkins' machine: All three were excellent on the defensive, and showed a brand of football that was far abOve anything their

PRICE 10 CENTS
STUDENT COUNCIL MAKES
SEVERAL IMPORTANT
ANNOUNCEMENTS.
Council to Meet First Tuesday in Each
Month—Freshman-Sophomore Football Game December 4—Honor
System Holds Good in Quizzes
as Well as Exams.

Several important announcements were made at the last assembly by President Stansbury, of
'the Student Council. The Student
Council will, in the future, meet
regularly on the first Tuesday of
each month, when any questions
that require its attention may be
presented.
The Freshman-Sophomore football game will be held Saturday,
December 4. The annual rush will
be staged between the halves, with
an additional period of ten minutes after the game, in the event
that the Sophs are unable to capture the flag in the first clash.
A ruling on the method of determining class standing was also
announced. For the first two
years, the year of residence at the
University will decide the class to
which a man belongs; thereafter,
he will be placed by the number of
points which he has acquired.
Residence at another college during the entire period of Freshman
regulations will entitle a man to
Sophomore standing.
The Council further decided to
interpret the Honor System as
applying to quizzes as well as
examinations.
In the future, the name "Johns
Hopkins Cotillon" is to be used
only when the Board giving the
dance is elected by the various
classes. The fraternities are free
to give Inter-Fraternity Cotillons,
provided they are so named.
BLACK AND BLUE JAY TO
APPEAR WEDNESDAY.
Should Pay Subscriptions in Advance—
Special Offer to Students Desiring to Take Outside Subscriptions.

The long-heralded Thanksgiving
number of the Black and Blue Jay
will be distributed at the University on Wednesday, November 24.
All students, who have paid for
their subscriptions shall receive
copies in their postoffice boxes.
Those who have not paid for the
magazine may receive copies at the
General Assembly Wednesday by
giving their names to the representatives of the Black and Blue
Jay at the Assembly. As only a

ORATORICAL CLUB.

The Oratorical Club is to hold
its first formal debate December
3. The subject is: "Resolved, That
political prisoners incarcerated
during the war should be released." Mr. Bernard Ades is the
speaker of the affirmative and Mr.
Albert Langeluttig the exponent
of the negative. Following the
debate there will be a general discussion of the question and the
club will record its opinion on the
matter by a resolution. Mr. Dorsey Watkins will then deliver a
short address on "The One-Year
Eligibility Rule."
The program of the next meeting carries both national and local
significance and it is hoped that a
number of students will attend.
The apathy concernifig the art of
public speaking has been manifest at the University and the Oratorical Club wishes to arouse interest in the most essential requisite of a college man-the ability
to express himself. The Oratorical
Club, besides affording practice
in self-expression, enables one to
become familiar with the most
pertinent questions of national
and college life. The Oratorical
Club also provides a means by
which one may become acquainted
with a large number of fellowstudents whom he would not have
become associated with in the
class rooms.
At the last meeting of the Oratorical Club Mr: Bernard Ades
spoke on "A Mitchell Palmer and
His Actions While Custodian of
Alien Property," and Mr. Albert
Desmond commented on "The Recent Republican Victory and the
Problems that Confront the New
Administration."
• Negotiations are now being carried on with the Literary Society
of Loyola College in an endeavor
to arrange an inter-club debate.

R. 0. T. C. IMPRESSES
INSPECTORS.
General Haan and Colonel Morrow
Seem Well Pleased With Work
Being Done.

The Hopkins Unit of the R. 0.
T. C. seems to have made quite a
favorable impression on General
Haan of the War Plans Division
and Colonel Morrow, chief of all
the R. 0. T. C. units. The inspectors were the guests of the
Military Department last Tuesday, when Major Garey explained
in detail the workings of our system of military education. During
the morning the visitors were
present at recitations in theoretical work and seemed pleased with
the accuracy of the answers given
to questions. Several individuals
were complimented on the especially good recitations which they
made. Drill in the afternoon was
prevented by inclement weather;
the First-Year men accordingly
worked in the tunnel of Gilman
Hall and the remainder of the
unit in the class rooms. Major
Garey expressed himself as more
than pleased with the conduct of
the battalion during the inspection.
GEOLOGY FIELD TRIP.

The Geology I Class was taken
on a field trip by Dr. Swartz last
Wednesday afternoon. The class
started at 1.30 P. M. and went by
trolley to Brooklyn, where they
studied the effects of the constant
beating of the water against the
shore line. The class originally
planned to go out on the bay itself
to study wave motion, but were
prevented from doing so by the
biting wind. The class returned
at 5.30 o'clock • all but frozen to
death.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS ORCHESTRA

A Complete Symphony Orchestra, now in Its Third Season. 85 Members Last Year.
CHARLES H. BOCHAU
Conductor
BART WIRTZ
Assistant Conductor
Members of Faculty Peabody Conservatory

Rehearsals Tuesday Evenings, 8-10, Concert Hall Peabody
Institute. Membership in the Orchestra open free of charge
to all members of the University and to outside musicians,
both men and women.

EDWIN L. TURNBULL,
President
FRED. H. GOTTLIEB
Vice-Pres.

PROF. JOHN B. WHITEHEAD
Treasurer

Players of wind and string instruments desiring to join
the Orchestra, should apply to Mr. Bochau, 304 E. North
Avenue (Telephone HomeWood 3079-J) or at rehearsals.

FERD. C. SMITH
Executive Secretary

TRUSTEES

A splendid opportunity to study standard orchestral
works under an experienced professional conductor.

The Johns Hopkins Musical Association
Organized to promote good music in the University and
community.

The Johns Hopkins lacrosse team
is not alone in its policy of holding fall practice. At many of
the leading Northern colleges and
universities large squads are in
active training, and prospects are
reported to be bright for excellent
twelves.
Interest in the sport
seems to be growing, especially at
those colleges which have only recently taken up the game, while
the members of the Intercollegiate
Lacrosse Association are also hard
at work.
The team of Lehigh University,
which last year won the intercollegiate title, has been hard hit by
the graduation of seven of its
regulars; but with a preliminary
squad of 40 anticipates no difficulty in filling their places. Many
promising candidates have reported and are being given regular
work-outs.
At Syracuse a contest in stickwork was recently held, with a
prize of a new stick for the winner
in the experienced class and a new
lacrosse ball for the most proficient beginner. Much benefit
has been gained from the competition and a lot of enthusiasm
aroused. The University of Pennsylvania has also gotten an early
start, while the other colleges are
not far behind. Hopkins will
have to put in some real work to
retain her place in the lacrosse
world.

HULLABALOO PROGRESSING.

The work on the 1921 Hullabaloo is rapidly progressing as
the contracts are being made. Mr.
Kennady, the business manager,
in making his agreement with the
photographer, has found it necessary to make a very exact estimate
of the number, both individual
and group photographs. He finds
that if the officers of each organization will notify him of the number of pictures they each desire
that they will greatly facilitate
the work of the board.
The book this year is one of the
best ever. There are four or five
members of the University who
are taking photographs of unusual
events and will later take an individual snapshot of each senior.
The book, contrary to any rumors
which may be circulating about it,
is not by any means a senior annual, but a book gotten up by a
representative board for the whole
student-body.

DR. FRANK J. GOODNOW
President of the University
PROF. JOHN H. LATANE
Dean Undergraduate School

The casts for the two plays to
be presented by the Dramatic Club
on Tuesday, November 23, at 8.15
P. M., have been rehearsing every
night to perfect the acting, so as
to make them as finished as possible. The scenery will only be suggestive and all hand-made, but will
suggest very clearly the desired
atmosphere. Except for a few
cigars and books and the revolver
everything was made by the property men out of material easily accessible and to conform to the
Bohemian atmosphere of the
studio in the "Barn."

Extraordinary," a melodrama, will
be put on first, with Pearce Brawner as Lester, Messersmith as
Margaret Graham, Junifer as
George and G. L. Sadtler as Boggs,
the butler.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS- NEWS-LETTER, NOVEMBER 23, 1920
MAY HAVE NEW COURSE TO BE
KNOWN AS "CONTEMPORARY
CIVILIZATION" NEXT YEAR.

Freshmen at the University
next year will probably have an
opportunity to take a new course,
to be known as "Contemporary
Civilization," if plans made last
Thursday evening at a meeting of
the Board of Collegiate Studies go
into .effect. At this meeting Prof.
J. J. Coss of Columbia University
addressed the board on the subject of the new study, which• has
been taught at Columbia during
the past year, and apparently the
board is favorably inclined
toward the establishment of the
course.
According to Dr. Arthur 0.
Lovejoy, professor of philosophy,
the course will be one which apparently teaches the Freshman a
little of everything, which will obviously be a very valuable addition to the list of courses now
taught here. The suggestion has
been made that the course be
taught to the upper-classmen also,
as it is conceivably possible that
some of them might be able to assimilate a small amount of additional knowledge.
The course is an entirely new
thing in American pedagogy, and
if Hopkins adopts it, it will be
the second university in the
United States to establish such a
course. The course was started at
Columbia last year, and has
proved very efficient in giving the
students a broad general knowledge of the world in which they
live. Dr. Lovejoy states that the
course will cover a wide range of
subjects, such a§ history, geography, commerce, politics, religion,
education, races, arts and other
pertinent information about the
various nations of the world. "It
Will be in no sense a historicalgeographical dissertation," said
Dr. Lovejoy, "but will give the
student an excellent ,general insight into the modern world."

FIELD CLUB.

It has been announced that Edward Speaker will talk before the
Hopkins Field Club at its meeting today in Room 10, Gilman
Hall. He will tell of his experiences last summer, when, as a
member of the United States Geological Expedition, he travelled
through the Peace Valley in Canada.
The Field Club is now getting
under way for what gives promise
of being its most successful season.
The Club has been replacing
the old bird-houses on the campus
with new and modern ones, and
is going to undertake to feed as
many birds as possible this winter.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, NOVEMBER 23, 1920
THE NEWS LETTER'S
MAILBAG
A Column in Which the Correspondents
Are Allowed Latitude, But Shoulder the Responsibility.
All letters intended for publication
must be concise.
No attention will be paid to anonymous letters, but names signed as an
evidence of good faith will not be printed
if request is made that they be omitted.
The publication of a letter is not to be
taken as an indorsement of its views by
THE NEWS-LETTER, which invites the
freest discussion of matters of general
Interest.

To the Editor of The Mail Bag:
Dear Sir — Every Freshman,
Upon entering • the University,
hears more or less anti-Hopkins
propaganda. Such propaganda
may, in every case, be traced to
some inactive student who has
done and will continue to do nothing to further the progress of the
University.
Though
our undergraduate
school is comparatively young, it
has, since its removal to Homewood, grown in leaps and bounds,
having had each year more applicants than could be accommodated. The great strides that it
has been making in its activities,
both athletic and non-athletic,
have been all that could have been
expected, and are serving rapidly
to place Hopkins in the rank of
larger universities.
Every Freshman should bear in
mind that the Hopkins of the
future shall be what he makes it,
and should each, now in his first
year, become an active member of
some activity. In such a manher
he will prove his loyalty and will
deal a blow to the above-mentioned
propagandists.
A JUNIOR.

BASKETBALL.
The Basketball team representing Johns Hopkins University
will begin practice December 6 at
the Fifth Regiment Armory. The
schedule has not been completed
as yet but 11 home games will be
arranged for and four games will
be played away from home. Plans
are being made to arrange a game
with the Crescent Athletic Club
of Brooklyn with whom Hopkins
has had such pleasant lacrosse relations during past years. The
season will close February 25 with
the University of Virginia game
at Baltimore, which promises to be
one of the best games of the season
due to rivalry existing between
the two universities in all lines of
athletics.
During the month of January it
is planned to have a game every
Friday evening, after which there
will be dancing; during February
there will be two games on Fridays.
Practice will be held in the late
afternoons, and from present indications a very successful season
may be looked for.
Bascom Kennady is acting manager of the basketball team.

SENIOR CLASS MEETING. '
The Senior Class held a most
important meeting last Thursday
at 12.30 o'clock in Room 110, M.
E. The class was first addressed
by R. J. Merrick, '17, about the
privilege of joining the Johns Hopkins Club, a privilege which is now
offered to members of the Senior
Class at the beginning of the academic year instead of late in the
spring as heretofore. He left some
subscription blanks which he requested when filled to be put in
P. 0. Box 388. The dues of the
club are $10 a year.
The class then voted that the
budget which is being prepared by
Mr. Bascom Kennady and T. F.
Hubbard be presented at the next
meeting. This budget will cover
the cost of every expenditure
which a Senior will be called upon
to make this year, including dues,
Hullabaloos, pictures, banquet,
Senior prom, class day exercises
and memorials. A rough estimate
shows that this will amount to between $25 and $40. A committee
composed of James Reed, Graham
Heiner and Edward Taylor was
appointed to determine what meas-

ures could be taken to assure the
collection of this sum and the pun( THE BOOK MART)

An attendant, perspiring freely
from sundry trips to the flying
field to carry gas and oil for the
planes, had.reached the end of his
patience. Each trip he had been
delayed by inquisitive persons
who bombarded him with Foolish
Questions Nos. 1-1000, inclusive.
Finally an old lady stopped him:
"Young man," she said, "what
do you do when a machine gets up
in the air and runs out of gasoline?"
"Confidentially, ma'am," he replied, "that2s just What's happened
now. .There's a couple of them
stalled up there and we've got to
take gas up in the emergency balloon to bring them down."—Amerjean Legion Weekly.

VOL. XXV. No. 8
NON-ATHLETIC FEE PASSED
UNANIMOUSLY BY
STUDENT-BODY.
Fee to Correspond to Athletic Fee—
Will Include all Non-Athletic Activities on the Campus—Will
be Presented to Trustees
for Sanction.

At the General Assembly of
last week the following resolution
concerning the establishment of a
non-athletic fee was passed by the
student-body by an almost unanimous vote:
ResQlved, That we, the studentbody of Johns Hopkins University,
request the ,Board of Trustees to
establish a fee of $10 to be devoted
to non-athletie activities, which
fee is to be paid by each student
upon entrance to the University
as is the present athletic fee.
Bascom Kennady presented the
subject to the meeting, explaining
the many advantages of the plan
and the tentative scheme of apportionment that has been drawn up.
Such an arrangement, he said, has
worked well at other colleges, removing the chance of failure of the
activities, increasing their efficiency, and placing the burden of
support equally on the shoulders
of all. Several men prominent in
campus activities were next called
on, and were all enthusiastic in
their support. Among them were
Ed Wood, captain of the Football
Team and Athletic Board President; Bill Wood and Elmer Jones,
'football stars; Mullikin, President of the Senior Class; Fedder,
President of the Zionist Society;
Heiner, of the Omicron 'DeJta
Kappa, and Stansbury, of the
Student Council.

BALTIMORE, MD., NOVEMBER 23, 1920

WESTERN MARYLAND FALLS BEFORE
HOPKINS MACHINE
Black and Blue Steam Roller Rolls Up 49 to 0 Score
Against Green and Gold.

The Hopkins' steam roller, after beginning with Haverford and
gathering momentum against St. John's, crushed the Western Maryland eleven last Saturday, and flattened it out to the tune of. 49 to 0.
The desperate efforts of the Green and Gold were completely smothered
by the slashing (play of the "Big Black" team; the Hopkins' backs
dashed almost at will through and around the Up-Staters' line, while
the clever Black and Blue forward gave the secondary defense almost
nothing to do.
John Markell was again responsible for most of the spectacular
back field work, although closely followed by Erie Calkins, who returned
to the game after being out for several weeks. Time after time these
two men, aided by splendid interference, plowed their way for long
gains, and were stopped onlY by Western Maryland's last defense. Even
this finally failed when Markel' scored on a 20-yard run, and Calkins
later on intercepted a forward pass and sprinted 50 yards for a touchdown. Jones and Cashell, although they did their share in carrying
the ball, stood out most clearly on the defensive and backed up the line
in faultless style, while ,Gregg, beside handling the team well, made
the longest run of the day on an interceptod pass, only to lose the result
of his work through a penalty for off-side play.
The highest praise that can be given the Black and Blue line is to
say that it played wit halmost machine-like precision, so that each man
occupied the spotlight at one time 'or another, and no one player stood
far above his fellows. Bill Wood exhibited his usual brilliant game at
end, while "Ti!" Morgan broke through the Green and Gold line with
regularity and downed the runner before he had a chance to start.
Captain Ward, at tackle, and; Langrall and Phillips, on the wings,
were responsible for whatever opposition the Up-Staters were able to
offer to the Hopkins' machine: All three were excellent on the defensive, and showed a brand of football that was far abOve anything their

STUDENT COUNCIL MAKES
SEVERAL IMPORTANT
ANNOUNCEMENTS.
Council to Meet First Tuesday in Each
Month—Freshman-Sophomore Football Game December 4—Honor
System Holds Good in Quizzes
as Well as Exams.

Several important announcements were made at the last assembly by President Stansbury, of
'the Student Council. The Student
Council will, in the future, meet
regularly on the first Tuesday of
each month, when any questions
that require its attention may be
presented.
The Freshman-Sophomore football game will be held Saturday,
December 4. The annual rush will
be staged between the halves, with
an additional period of ten minutes after the game, in the event
that the Sophs are unable to capture the flag in the first clash.
A ruling on the method of determining class standing was also
announced. For the first two
years, the year of residence at the
University will decide the class to
which a man belongs; thereafter,
he will be placed by the number of
points which he has acquired.
Residence at another college during the entire period of Freshman
regulations will entitle a man to
Sophomore standing.
The Council further decided to
interpret the Honor System as
applying to quizzes as well as
examinations.
In the future, the name "Johns
Hopkins Cotillon" is to be used
only when the Board giving the
dance is elected by the various
classes. The fraternities are free
to give Inter-Fraternity Cotillons,
provided they are so named.

number of the Black and Blue Jay

magazine may receive copies at the

ORATORICAL CLUB.

The Oratorical Club is to hold
its first formal debate December
3. The subject is: "Resolved, That
political prisoners incarcerated
during the war should be released." Mr. Bernard Ades is the
speaker of the affirmative and Mr.
Albert Langeluttig the exponent
of the negative. Following the
debate there will be a general discussion of the question and the
club will record its opinion on the
matter by a resolution. Mr. Dorsey Watkins will then deliver a
short address on "The One-Year
Eligibility Rule."
The program of the next meeting carries both national and local
significance and it is hoped that a
number of students will attend.
The apathy concernifig the art of
public speaking has been manifest at the University and the Oratorical Club wishes to arouse interest in the most essential requisite of a college man-the ability
to express himself. The Oratorical
Club, besides affording practice
in self-expression, enables one to
become familiar with the most
pertinent questions of national
and college life. The Oratorical
Club also provides a means by
which one may become acquainted
with a large number of fellowstudents whom he would not have
become associated with in the
class rooms.
At the last meeting of the Oratorical Club Mr: Bernard Ades
spoke on "A Mitchell Palmer and
His Actions While Custodian of
Alien Property," and Mr. Albert
Desmond commented on "The Recent Republican Victory and the
Problems that Confront the New
Administration."
• Negotiations are now being carried on with the Literary Society
of Loyola College in an endeavor
to arrange an inter-club debate.

R. 0. T. C. IMPRESSES
INSPECTORS.
General Haan and Colonel Morrow
Seem Well Pleased With Work
Being Done.

The Hopkins Unit of the R. 0.
T. C. seems to have made quite a
favorable impression on General
Haan of the War Plans Division
and Colonel Morrow, chief of all
the R. 0. T. C. units. The inspectors were the guests of the
Military Department last Tuesday, when Major Garey explained
in detail the workings of our system of military education. During
the morning the visitors were
present at recitations in theoretical work and seemed pleased with
the accuracy of the answers given
to questions. Several individuals
were complimented on the especially good recitations which they
made. Drill in the afternoon was
prevented by inclement weather;
the First-Year men accordingly
worked in the tunnel of Gilman
Hall and the remainder of the
unit in the class rooms. Major
Garey expressed himself as more
than pleased with the conduct of
the battalion during the inspection.
GEOLOGY FIELD TRIP.

The Geology I Class was taken
on a field trip by Dr. Swartz last
Wednesday afternoon. The class
started at 1.30 P. M. and went by
trolley to Brooklyn, where they
studied the effects of the constant
beating of the water against the
shore line. The class originally
planned to go out on the bay itself
to study wave motion, but were
prevented from doing so by the
biting wind. The class returned
at 5.30 o'clock • all but frozen to
death.

TRUSTEES

A splendid opportunity to study standard orchestral
works under an experienced professional conductor.

The Johns Hopkins Musical Association
Organized to promote good music in the University and
community.

The Johns Hopkins lacrosse team
is not alone in its policy of holding fall practice. At many of
the leading Northern colleges and
universities large squads are in
active training, and prospects are
reported to be bright for excellent
twelves.
Interest in the sport
seems to be growing, especially at
those colleges which have only recently taken up the game, while
the members of the Intercollegiate
Lacrosse Association are also hard
at work.
The team of Lehigh University,
which last year won the intercollegiate title, has been hard hit by
the graduation of seven of its
regulars; but with a preliminary
squad of 40 anticipates no difficulty in filling their places. Many
promising candidates have reported and are being given regular
work-outs.
At Syracuse a contest in stickwork was recently held, with a
prize of a new stick for the winner
in the experienced class and a new
lacrosse ball for the most proficient beginner. Much benefit
has been gained from the competition and a lot of enthusiasm
aroused. The University of Pennsylvania has also gotten an early
start, while the other colleges are
not far behind. Hopkins will
have to put in some real work to
retain her place in the lacrosse
world.

HULLABALOO PROGRESSING.

The work on the 1921 Hullabaloo is rapidly progressing as
the contracts are being made. Mr.
Kennady, the business manager,
in making his agreement with the
photographer, has found it necessary to make a very exact estimate
of the number, both individual
and group photographs. He finds
that if the officers of each organization will notify him of the number of pictures they each desire
that they will greatly facilitate
the work of the board.
The book this year is one of the
best ever. There are four or five
members of the University who
are taking photographs of unusual
events and will later take an individual snapshot of each senior.
The book, contrary to any rumors
which may be circulating about it,
is not by any means a senior annual, but a book gotten up by a
representative board for the whole
student-body.

DR. FRANK J. GOODNOW
President of the University
PROF. JOHN H. LATANE
Dean Undergraduate School

THE JOHNS HOPKINS- NEWS-LETTER, NOVEMBER 23, 1920
MAY HAVE NEW COURSE TO BE
KNOWN AS "CONTEMPORARY
CIVILIZATION" NEXT YEAR.

Freshmen at the University
next year will probably have an
opportunity to take a new course,
to be known as "Contemporary
Civilization," if plans made last
Thursday evening at a meeting of
the Board of Collegiate Studies go
into .effect. At this meeting Prof.
J. J. Coss of Columbia University
addressed the board on the subject of the new study, which• has
been taught at Columbia during
the past year, and apparently the
board is favorably inclined
toward the establishment of the
course.
According to Dr. Arthur 0.
Lovejoy, professor of philosophy,
the course will be one which apparently teaches the Freshman a
little of everything, which will obviously be a very valuable addition to the list of courses now
taught here. The suggestion has
been made that the course be
taught to the upper-classmen also,
as it is conceivably possible that
some of them might be able to assimilate a small amount of additional knowledge.
The course is an entirely new
thing in American pedagogy, and
if Hopkins adopts it, it will be
the second university in the
United States to establish such a
course. The course was started at
Columbia last year, and has
proved very efficient in giving the
students a broad general knowledge of the world in which they
live. Dr. Lovejoy states that the
course will cover a wide range of
subjects, such a§ history, geography, commerce, politics, religion,
education, races, arts and other
pertinent information about the
various nations of the world. "It
Will be in no sense a historicalgeographical dissertation," said
Dr. Lovejoy, "but will give the
student an excellent ,general insight into the modern world."

FIELD CLUB.

It has been announced that Edward Speaker will talk before the
Hopkins Field Club at its meeting today in Room 10, Gilman
Hall. He will tell of his experiences last summer, when, as a
member of the United States Geological Expedition, he travelled
through the Peace Valley in Canada.
The Field Club is now getting
under way for what gives promise
of being its most successful season.
The Club has been replacing
the old bird-houses on the campus
with new and modern ones, and
is going to undertake to feed as
many birds as possible this winter.

THE NEWS LETTER'S
MAILBAG
A Column in Which the Correspondents
Are Allowed Latitude, But Shoulder the Responsibility.
All letters intended for publication
must be concise.
No attention will be paid to anonymous letters, but names signed as an
evidence of good faith will not be printed
if request is made that they be omitted.
The publication of a letter is not to be
taken as an indorsement of its views by
THE NEWS-LETTER, which invites the
freest discussion of matters of general
Interest.

To the Editor of The Mail Bag:
Dear Sir — Every Freshman,
Upon entering • the University,
hears more or less anti-Hopkins
propaganda. Such propaganda
may, in every case, be traced to
some inactive student who has
done and will continue to do nothing to further the progress of the
University.
Though
our undergraduate
school is comparatively young, it
has, since its removal to Homewood, grown in leaps and bounds,
having had each year more applicants than could be accommodated. The great strides that it
has been making in its activities,
both athletic and non-athletic,
have been all that could have been
expected, and are serving rapidly
to place Hopkins in the rank of
larger universities.
Every Freshman should bear in
mind that the Hopkins of the
future shall be what he makes it,
and should each, now in his first
year, become an active member of
some activity. In such a manher
he will prove his loyalty and will
deal a blow to the above-mentioned
propagandists.
A JUNIOR.

BASKETBALL.
The Basketball team representing Johns Hopkins University
will begin practice December 6 at
the Fifth Regiment Armory. The
schedule has not been completed
as yet but 11 home games will be
arranged for and four games will
be played away from home. Plans
are being made to arrange a game
with the Crescent Athletic Club
of Brooklyn with whom Hopkins
has had such pleasant lacrosse relations during past years. The
season will close February 25 with
the University of Virginia game
at Baltimore, which promises to be
one of the best games of the season
due to rivalry existing between
the two universities in all lines of
athletics.
During the month of January it
is planned to have a game every
Friday evening, after which there
will be dancing; during February
there will be two games on Fridays.
Practice will be held in the late
afternoons, and from present indications a very successful season
may be looked for.
Bascom Kennady is acting manager of the basketball team.

SENIOR CLASS MEETING. '
The Senior Class held a most
important meeting last Thursday
at 12.30 o'clock in Room 110, M.
E. The class was first addressed
by R. J. Merrick, '17, about the
privilege of joining the Johns Hopkins Club, a privilege which is now
offered to members of the Senior
Class at the beginning of the academic year instead of late in the
spring as heretofore. He left some
subscription blanks which he requested when filled to be put in
P. 0. Box 388. The dues of the
club are $10 a year.
The class then voted that the
budget which is being prepared by
Mr. Bascom Kennady and T. F.
Hubbard be presented at the next
meeting. This budget will cover
the cost of every expenditure
which a Senior will be called upon
to make this year, including dues,
Hullabaloos, pictures, banquet,
Senior prom, class day exercises
and memorials. A rough estimate
shows that this will amount to between $25 and $40. A committee
composed of James Reed, Graham
Heiner and Edward Taylor was
appointed to determine what meas-

ures could be taken to assure the
collection of this sum and the pun( THE BOOK MART)

An attendant, perspiring freely
from sundry trips to the flying
field to carry gas and oil for the
planes, had.reached the end of his
patience. Each trip he had been
delayed by inquisitive persons
who bombarded him with Foolish
Questions Nos. 1-1000, inclusive.
Finally an old lady stopped him:
"Young man," she said, "what
do you do when a machine gets up
in the air and runs out of gasoline?"
"Confidentially, ma'am," he replied, "that2s just What's happened
now. .There's a couple of them
stalled up there and we've got to
take gas up in the emergency balloon to bring them down."—Amerjean Legion Weekly.
